metadata.case_name: Mannalal Jain v. State of Assam & Ors.

facts.text: Petitioner Mannalal Jain is an Indian citizen carrying on business dealing in rice and paddy in the district of Kamrup in the State of Assam.
In 1955, the Essential Commodities Act, 1955 (Act 10 of 1955) was enacted.

In exercise of powers under s.3 of the Act read with notification delegating powers to Government of Assam, the Assam Foodgrains Licensing and Control Order, 1958 was made, requiring license for dealing in rice and paddy in wholesale quantities.
Petitioner obtained a license in 1958, which expired on December 31, 1958.
In 1959, petitioner carried on business, though dispute as to whether he obtained a license for that year.

On November 26, 1959, petitioner received letter from Deputy Director of Supply, Gauhati, stating his license would not be renewed after December 31, 1959, due to decision to give monopoly procurement of paddy to Assam Co-operative Apex Marketing Society Ltd. (respondent No. 6).

Letter dated November 13, 1959 from Director of Supply, Assam, indicated policy of monopoly procurement right to Co-operative Apex Marketing Society in Kamrup district including Mangaldai Sub-division etc.

On January 5, 1960, Assam Foodgrains Licensing and Control Order, 1960 came into force, replacing 1958 Order. Clause 5 specified matters for granting/refusing license: stock available, number of licenses, business carried on, past activities.
Petitioner applied for license for 1960 on January 28, 1960.

Application rejected on February 17, 1960: 'as the Co-operative Apex Marketing Society has been given the right of monopoly purchase in the Kamrup district this year, your case cannot be considered for issue of the license.'
Petitioner moved High Court of Assam under Art. 226; High Court allowed petition, quashed order dated February 17, 1960, issued mandamus to consider application on merits per cl.5 of 1960 Order.
No order passed till June 7, 1960; petitioner applied to High Court for direction to grant license and contempt.

On June 8, 1960, licensing authority rejected: 'As the Assam Co-operative Apex Marketing Society Ltd. has already been granted a license... it is considered unnecessary to grant further dealing licenses to individual dealers.'
Petitioner withdrew June 7 applications, filed fresh on June 15, 1960 against June 8 order.
High Court on August 10, 1960 set aside June 8 order, directed licensing authority to act independently of government instructions, apply mind to merits per 1960 Order.
No order till September 8, 1960; petitioner applied for enforcement and contempt.

On September 13, 1960, licensing authority rejected: 'Assam Co-operative Apex Marketing Society Ltd. has been granted license... relevant under Clause 5(b)... stock can be procured by them... better facility... no necessity to grant license.'
Petitioner filed writ petition in Supreme Court on October 17, 1960 (No. 303 of 1960).
Hearing on February 2, 1961 adjourned sine die as 1960 license period expired; fresh application needed for 1961.
Fresh Assam Foodgrains Licensing and Control Order, 1961 made before February 4, 1961.
Petitioner made fresh application on February 4, 1961 under 1961 Order.
Petitioner filed C.M.P. No. 850 of 1961 seeking direction to consider and grant license.

On April 11, 1961, licensing authority rejected: 'Having regard to the existing licenses in these areas Mangaldai and Gauhati, and the quantity of foodgrains available therein, any further license would be superfluous.'
Petition heard May 1, 1961; time granted to amend original petition to challenge April 11, 1961 order; amendment allowed via C.M.P. No. 1140 of 1961 dated May 5, 1961.
Clause 5 of 1961 Order added sub-cl. (e): 'whether the applicant is a co-operative society'; omitted proviso to old cl.5.
On November 10, 1960, High Court rejected contempt application as September 13, 1960 order not before it.
Affidavits show private dealers completely excluded in 1961; licenses issued to co-operatives in all paddy producing districts.

legal_issues.text: Whether sub-cl. (e) of cl.5 of the Assam Foodgrains Licensing and Control Order, 1961 is ultra vires s.3 read with s.5 of Essential Commodities Act, 1955.
Whether the licensing authority properly considered the application on merits per cl.5, or acted on government instructions to create monopoly for co-operatives, violating Arts. 14 and 19.

petitioner_arguments.text: Sub-cl. (e) of cl.5 of 1961 Order ultra vires as whether applicant is co-operative society irrelevant to objects of s.3 (maintaining/increasing supplies or equitable distribution at fair prices).

Even if intra vires, sub-cl.(e) allows consideration among other matters, does not create monopoly; licensing authority proceeded on footing of monopoly per government instructions, despite High Court directions, colourable exercise of power, discriminatory, violates Arts.14 and 19(1)(g).
Grant of license to respondent No.6 should be quashed.

respondent_arguments.text: Sub-cl.(e) within powers under s.3 and s.5 of 1955 Act.
No monopoly granted to respondent No.6; April 11, 1961 order based on cl.5(a) and (b) (existing licenses, quantity available); not assailable under Art.32.
Co-operatives have better facilities for procuring foodgrains, ensure fair prices to farmers, eliminate middlemen; policy per National Development Council to prefer co-operatives.

court_reasoning.text: Cl.5 of 1961 Order does not create monopoly; enumerates matters among others to consider; sub-cl.(e) allows preference to co-operatives in certain circumstances, related to s.3 objects as co-operatives better positioned in village economy for supplies and fair prices.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sub-cl.(e) not ultra vires; has reasonable relation to Act's objects.

court_reasoning.text: Licensing authority refused license not on cl.5 grounds but to create monopoly per government instructions; orders show reliance on monopoly policy; affidavits confirm private dealers excluded statewide via instructions, not per cl.5 which allows preference, not monopoly.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Discrimination in administration of law for ulterior object, violates Arts.14,19.

court_reasoning.text: Dissent (Sarkar J.): Sub-cl.(e) valid as preference to co-operatives advances Act objects by eliminating middlemen, fair prices; no discrimination, reasonable restriction under Art.19(6); no evidence of acting on instructions for 1961.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Giving trade to co-operatives reasonable; structure benefits growers/consumers.

holdings.text: Sub-cl.(e) of cl.5 of 1961 Order intra vires Essential Commodities Act.

Impugned order dated April 11, 1961 quashed as based on instructions for monopoly, not cl.5; violates Arts.14,19; license to respondent No.6 also quashed; direct reconsideration on merits per cl.5, ignoring inconsistent instructions.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ramanlal Nagardas v. M. S. Palnitkar
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinguished as no discrimination between classes of license-holders there; here, improper monopoly creation via administration.

precedents_cited.case_name: Narendra Kumar v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Prohibition/restriction reasonable if serves general public interest; middlemen elimination axiomatic for fair prices.

precedents_cited.case_name: Glass Chatons Importers Users Association v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Canalisation through agencies reasonable if in general public interest.

statutes_cited.name: Essential Commodities Act, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Powers to make orders for regulating trade in essential commodities; delegation to State; cl.5 of Orders must relate to maintaining supplies/equitable distribution at fair prices.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Equality, right to trade, reasonable restrictions; writ jurisdiction.

statutes_cited.name: Assam Foodgrains Licensing and Control Order, 1958
Assam Foodgrains Licensing and Control Order, 1960
statutes_cited.relevance: Matters for license grant/refusal; High Court directed compliance.

statutes_cited.name: Assam Foodgrains Licensing and Control Order, 1961
statutes_cited.relevance: Matters including whether applicant co-operative society; allows preference, not monopoly.

outcome.summary: Petition allowed with costs. Impugned order of April 11, 1961 and license to respondent No.6 quashed. Licensing authority directed to reconsider petitioner's and others' applications for 1961 on merits per cl.5 of 1961 Order, ignoring inconsistent instructions, expeditiously.
outcome.relief_granted: Quashing of orders; mandamus for fresh consideration on merits.

key_quotes.text: "The duty of the licensing authority was to pass orders in accordance with cl. 5 of the Control Order, 1961. Instead of doing that, it passed an order in accordance with the instructions given to it on behalf of the State Government".
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core finding on colourable exercise and violation of Arts.14,19.

key_quotes.text: "We express our deep concern over the manner in which the State Government or its officers have issued instructions... which clearly enough are not in consonance with the provisions of law... Such a method will destroy the very basis of the rule of law".
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Critique of executive instructions overriding law.

key_quotes.text: "That middlemans profits increase the price of goods which the consumer has to pay is axiomatic."
key_quotes.speaker: court
